data.text: Contents
Activating the cardiac arrest team (Main hospital sites) ................................................ 7
Introduction
It is recognised that some patients conditions will deteriorate into cardiorespiratory arrest and these situations require early and effective cardiopulmonary resuscitation to improve outcomes.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
State the expected standards of resuscitation performance within the Trust.
Outline the requirements for resuscitation training within the trust.
This policy covers the resuscitation of infants, children and adults

This policy does not cover the recognition or management of the deteriorating patient, decisions relating to resuscitation (Do not attempt Cardiopulmonary resuscitation), resuscitation at birth or the management of trauma.
Definitions

table_items.text: Basic life support – Includes conformation of cardiac arrest, initiation of chest compressions and ventilations
Automated External Defibrillator – A defibrillator with automated rhythm recognition. Computerised device designed to use voice and visual prompts to guide defibrillation.

National Cardiac Arrest Audit - The National Cardiac Arrest Audit (NCAA) is the national clinical audit of in-hospital cardiac arrests in the UK and Ireland. It is a joint initiative between the Resuscitation Council (UK) and Intensive Care National Audit & Research Centre
Kallidus LEARN - Learning management system used within the trust

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Managing Director

The Managing Director as the Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available. He/she will delegate the full implementation of this document to a relevant Executive Director.
Medical Director/Director of Nursing

Is responsible for ensuring that the standards and expectations of staff under this policy are clear, available, and implemented and dissemination through professional lines of accountability and that suitable arrangements are in place to measure outcome and compliance.
Divisional Clinical Directors

The Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that systems and processes are in place throughout their Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate. In addition, the Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that all medical and dental staff comply with the contents of this document.
Consultant Leads
Have the responsibility to ensure the clinical areas and staff in their Divisions implement and comply with the policy.
Divisional General Managers

The Divisional General Managers are responsible for implementing the systems and processes required throughout the Divisions, to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate.
Heads of Nursing

The Heads of Nursing Quality and Assurance are responsible for ensuring that this document is fully implemented at clinical departmental level. This will include making sure all relevant and necessary training is given and recorded, that the introduction of the document is monitored and the impact on service delivery is assessed through audit with adequate resources to support on-going review.
Clinical Service Unit Clinical Leads/ Unit Managers

Clinical Service Unit Clinical Leads and Unit Managers are responsible for implementing this document in the Clinical Service Unit and for monitoring and reporting compliance with the document. They are accountable to the Divisional Clinical Director and General Manager in this respect.
Matrons, Lead Nurses and Senior Sisters/Charge Nurses

Have responsibility for education and implementation of this policy within their allocated clinical area, ensuring staff understand their accountability and responsibility in relation to complying with the policy and ongoing audit and review of compliance.
Resuscitation service

Have a responsibility to update the Resuscitation Policy. The Resuscitation officers/practitioners have a responsibility to oversee and deliver Resuscitation practice and training and provide advice as the subject matter experts. They are responsible for the audit and monitoring of the resuscitation procedure and training compliance. The Resuscitation service is responsible for the collection and reporting of data required by the National Cardiac Arrest Audit (NCAA) and organisational audit. The resuscitation service also has a responsibility to maintain Resuscitation Council course centre status and to provide Resuscitation Council UK registered courses.
Duty telephonist

Have responsibility for clarifying the type of emergency, team required and location, summoning the appropriate emergency team using the group paging system, testing and documenting the emergency response pagers carried by the team members. They are also responsible for identifying team members who do not respond to the test pager and contacting them regarding the need to replace/repair the pager.
All staff

Have a responsibility to read this policy and understand their role in resuscitation procedures. They should ensure, where appropriate, that they are familiar with the resuscitation equipment in their area of employment / work. They must inform their manager of any constraints regarding their ability to perform resuscitation procedures and must attend mandatory resuscitation training and updates as appropriate to their role.
First Responder

The first responder is the individual initially assessing the patient. They should rapidly assess the patient and confirm cardiac arrest according to the techniques taught in their most recent life support training.

The first responder must ensure that the Medical emergency/Cardiac arrest team has been summoned by dialling 2222. Some Trust locations may need to call 999 for an ambulance as well as, or, instead of calling 2222.
The first responder should immediately start basic life support. If there is any doubt as to whether the patient is displaying signs of life basic life support should be commenced.
Activating the cardiac arrest team (Main hospital sites)
All emergency teams are activated via switchboard by dialling 2222 on an internal telephone.

In the event that an internal phone is not available (for example in a car park) a mobile phone can be used by dialling the appropriate site switchboard number and selecting the extension number 2222.
Table 1 identifies the current individual site activation methods and responsibilities.

In the event that an internal phone is not available (for example in a car park) a mobile phone can be used by dialling the appropriate site switchboard number and selecting the extension number 2222.
When activating a 2222 call the location (department) name must be stated in full, no abbreviations should be used.
Wait for the operator to repeat the emergency call details before terminating the phone call.

It is expected in all but the most extreme circumstances that the Cardiac arrest/medical emergency team will manage the cardiac arrest. A decision to call 9- 999 can be made on the instruction of the team leader, but only where it is determined that equipment or staff competencies held exclusively by the ambulance service are required.
If the team attend an out-patient, visitor or member of staff who requires ongoing acute assessment, examination or treatment they will be taken to the emergency department and handed over.

In Southend and Broomfield the team should place a pre alert call to the emergency department as soon as the decision is made that transfer is necessary (in Southend the pre alert number is displayed on the emergency trolley).

data.text: Switchboard responsibilities
The switchboard team will record details of all 2222 calls. These records must be shared with the site based resuscitation services to contribute towards the collection of data for the NCAA.
The Cardiac arrest bleeps must be tested at least once every  hours, according to the current switchboard SOP.
Amendments to the cardiac arrest team lists may only be made following consultation with the site based Resuscitation Service.
Cardiac arrest in external locations
In the event of cardiac arrest all locations external to the three MSE main hospital sites 999 should be called for an ambulance.
Basic life support including the use of an AED where available should be continued until the arrival of the emergency services.
A clinical incident report must be made for all cardiac arrests occurring on external sites
Additional site specific emergency actions

table_items.text: Dial 2222 for Orsett Medical emergency team. Orsett MET to attend with grab bag & AED and activate a 999 call to the Ambulance Service MET= Senior nurse from outpatients & NELFT Minor injuries nurse practitioner if available
Emergencies within Brentwood should be managed by the department staff with support from inpatient clinical teams if needed. An ambulance should be called via 999 if required.

data.text: Hospital Resuscitation teams
The team leader should hold a current advanced life support qualification (Resuscitation Council UK / Advanced Life Support Group) in the relevant speciality.

Prior to the arrival of the nominated team leader any member of staff who holds a current advanced life support qualification (RCUK / ALSG) in the relevant speciality may lead the team until the arrival of the nominated team leader.

Resuscitation process
Resuscitation attempts should be conducted according to current Resuscitation Council UK guidelines.
Consideration must be given to allowing relatives to remain present during resuscitation. Where relatives are present they must be supported by an appropriately experienced member of staff.
The presence of staff in addition to the defined cardiac arrest team must not impede the resuscitation attempt. Where appropriate some staff may be asked to leave.
Following successful resuscitation it is the responsibility of the team leader to refer to or liaise with the appropriate service or department to provide ongoing post resuscitation care.

The cardiac arrest team leader is responsible for ensuring that post resuscitation care is commenced immediately on return of spontaneous circulation and that it is continued during transfer to the appropriate service or clinical area.
After each resuscitation attempt, the team leader is responsible for ensuring that the Cardiac arrest is accurately documented in the patient's notes.
Following the resuscitation attempt, the 2222 audit document and a clinical incident report must be completed.
Resuscitation Equipment

All clinical areas will have resuscitation equipment appropriate to their patient population. Following an assessment of the area the site Resuscitation service will specify the trolley/grab bag requirements.
A record of the locations of trolleys, grab bags and defibrillators must be held by the site Resuscitation Service.
All areas with a resuscitation trolley/bag must also have portable suction and oxygen available.
All clinical areas will have immediate access to an appropriate defibrillator. Following an assessment of the area the Resuscitation service will specify the defibrillator required.

The resuscitation trolleys must be standardised across the local site. To reduce the risk of selection of the incorrect trolley in an emergency, no area may purchase or use the designated MSE resuscitation trolleys for any other purpose.

Each MSE site must have a standardised list of contents for the resuscitation trolley. This list is maintained by the Resuscitation Service. Without exception, all trolleys across the site must be maintained according to this checklist. No items may be altered, added or removed from this list with out the agreement of the site Resuscitation Service.
Each ward/departmental manager is responsible for ensuring that their areas have the correct equipment and that this equipment is in good working order.
Responsibility for allocating individuals to check the resuscitation equipment lies with the ward/department manager of that area, see table 3 for frequency of checking.
The storage location of trolleys and defibrillators must not be altered without the authorisation of the site resuscitation service

Once checked, all resuscitation grab bags and trolleys must be sealed with a numbered disposable seal. The only exception to this is where the facility doesn't exist to apply a seal. In order to be considered appropriate for the storage of resuscitation equipment, any new resuscitation bags purchased must have this facility.
All equipment checks must be recorded on the site specific documentation or log book.
All single use items must be stored in their original packaging, sealed and within date.
All emergency equipment must be cleaned, restocked, checked and sealed immediately after any emergency use.
Routine Resuscitation trolley & bag checking frequency:

table_items.text: Trolley seal intact Oxygen, suction & defibrillator daily check

data.text: If an area is moving or a new area is planned the site resuscitation service must be notified immediately. For all new areas the Resuscitation Service will advise on equipment requirements. It is the responsibility of the requesting manager to make arrangements for the procurement and preparation of consumables and equipment prior to opening to patients.

Faults identified with Resuscitation equipment must be raised immediately to MEMS when they are open, for out of hours faults contact the Site manager for advice. No area that has a defibrillator should be clinically open to patients without an operating defibrillator.

Endotracheal intubation is not to be attempted without immediate access to waveform end-tidal capnography. The appropriate defibrillator with waveform capnography should be sourced if intubation is required.
Training requirements

The environment in which training is provided, the facilities available and the training curriculum will reflect evidence based practice. Training will therefore be based on current research and Resuscitation Council UK guidelines

All resuscitation training within the trust must be facilitated by Resuscitation officers/practitioners, or appropriately qualified staff approved by the lead Resuscitation officer/practitioner for the site.
Resuscitation training is mandatory for all clinical staff and must be undertaken annually.

Individuals unable to complete resuscitation training due to disability or illness must undertake an appropriate risk assessment with their line manager and liaise with their site resuscitation team to consider adapted training if appropriate.
The level of training required will be determined by the Resuscitation Service in conjunction with department managers.

Doctors who act as cardiac arrest team leaders are expected to maintain their advanced level training qualifications. Doctors are also expected to meet the training requirements of their Deanery or recommendations of their Royal College.
All resuscitation training must be recorded on LEARN
Training across the MSE is provided according to Appendix 1
The trust will recognise Resuscitation Council and Advanced Life Support Group courses undertaken externally to the trust.

Resuscitation officers/practitioners are expected to attend Resuscitation Council and Advanced Life Support Group courses as instructors on a regular basis to enable them to maintain their knowledge, skills and credibility.
Any policy or guideline identifying levels of resuscitation training or standards will not be recognised or approved if the site Resuscitation Services have not been reviewed it.

Resuscitation training for non-employed individuals, for example parents of children with highly complex needs will be undertaken by staff approved by the site lead resuscitation Officer/Practitioner.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring

Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Local Audit & Data entry to NCAA
Trust board NCAA (produce quarterly report for each site)
Incidents or near miss reports relating to resuscitation issues

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Resuscitation/ Deteriorating Patient Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local resuscitation guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Resuscitation/Deteriorating Patient Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary Equality Analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
